image.altText: fresh fruit in aisles of a grocery shop

items.synopsis: Consumer inflation for the June quarter falls more than expected by economists, while the IMF warns of persistent challenges for the global economy. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Inflation falls to 6 per cent as interest rate hikes dampen demand, ASX surges, IMF warns of economic challenges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Investors have reacted quickly to the bigger than expected drop in inflation over the June quarter. The odds of a rate hike by the Reserve Bank next week have dropped with the market betting on a 29 per cent chance of a 0.25 per cent rise, and a 71 per cent chance that rates will stay on hold. The Australian dollar slumped and the Australian market increased to a five month high. The dollar fell nearly 1 per cent to 67.29 US cents because investors think the pull back in inflation buys the RBA more time to consider how the economy is tracking before it pulls the rate lever again. Rate hikes boost currencies because they increase the cost of money. The ASX 200 extended its gains by 0.8 per cent with investors also betting on a pause, although real estate firms are lower. Consumer staples did well on the news, but its banks and big miners that are driving the market today. Banks also extended their gains after the numbers came out. ANZ is up 1.5 per cent, while Westpac has put on 1.6 per cent. Even though banks make money from interest rate rises, higher borrowing costs also means a likely rise in loan defaults.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Investors see RBA pause

children.content: Investors have reacted quickly to the bigger than expected drop in inflation over the June quarter.
The odds of a rate hike by the Reserve Bank next week have dropped with the market betting on a 29 per cent chance of a 0.25 per cent rise, and a 71 per cent chance that rates will stay on hold.
The Australian dollar slumped and the Australian market increased to a five month high.

The dollar fell nearly 1 per cent to 67.29 US cents because investors think the pull back in inflation buys the RBA more time to consider how the economy is tracking before it pulls the rate lever again.
Rate hikes boost currencies because they increase the cost of money.
The ASX 200
extended its gains by 0.8 per cent with investors also betting on a pause, although real estate firms are lower.
Consumer staples did well on the news, but its banks and big miners that are driving the market today.
Banks also extended their gains after the numbers came out.
ANZ is up 1.5 per cent, while Westpac has put on 1.6 per cent.
Even though banks make money from interest rate rises, higher borrowing costs also means a likely rise in loan defaults.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: So this is where inflation's now sitting. The annual rate of headline inflation fell to 6 per cent in the June quarter, down from 7 per recent in the March quarter. It's the second consecutive quarter of lower annual inflation. This is known as " disinflation". Market economists were expecting the headline rate of annual inflation to fall to 6.2 per cent, so it's lower than they were anticipating. And what about underlying inflation? The Reserve Bank is particularly interested in underlying inflation, because that shows us what's happening to inflation when volatile price movements are stripped out of the headline figure. The ABS refers to underlying inflation as "trimmed mean" inflation. And it has fallen to 5.9 per cent in the June quarter, down from 6.6 per cent in the March quarter, and the peak in December 2022 of 6.9 per cent. When the RBA talks about wanting to get inflation back down into its 2-3% target range, it's talking about underlying/trimmed mean inflation. So it's heading back towards target.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: We're seeing 'disinflation'

children.content: So this is where inflation's now sitting.
The annual rate of
headline inflation fell to 6 per cent
in the June quarter,
down from 7 per recent
in the March quarter.
It's the second consecutive quarter of lower annual inflation. This is known as "
disinflation".
Market economists were expecting the headline rate of annual inflation to fall to 6.2 per cent, so it's lower than they were anticipating.
And what about underlying inflation?
The Reserve Bank is particularly interested in underlying inflation, because that shows us what's happening to inflation when volatile price movements are stripped out of the headline figure.
The ABS refers to underlying inflation as "trimmed mean" inflation.
And it has
fallen to 5.9 per cent
in the June quarter,
down from 6.6 per cent
in the March quarter, and the peak in December 2022 of 6.9 per cent.
When the RBA talks about wanting to get inflation back down into its 2-3% target range, it's talking about underlying/trimmed mean inflation.
So it's heading back towards target.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The latest inflation figures are out and it could see the RBA pause rate hikes again next month. The Bureau of Statistics says consumer prices rose by 0.8 per cent over the June quarter and by 6 per cent over the year to June. The most significant price rises were rents and international travel. That's a pull back from a 1.4 per cent rise over the March quarter and a 7 per cent increase over the year to March driven by gas and domestic travel. Economists predicted that inflation would rise by 1 per cent over the June quarter and by 6.2 per cent over the year to June. More coming up from Gareth Hutchens.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Inflation pulls back over June quarter

children.content: The latest inflation figures are out and it could see the RBA pause rate hikes again next month.
The Bureau of Statistics says consumer prices rose by 0.8 per cent over the June quarter and by 6 per cent over the year to June.
The most significant price rises were rents and
international travel.
That's a pull back from a 1.4 per cent rise over the March quarter and a 7 per cent increase over the year to March driven by gas and domestic travel.
Economists predicted that inflation would rise by 1 per cent over the June quarter and by 6.2 per cent over the year to June.
More coming up from Gareth Hutchens.
